text:
Saudi Arabian exports in 2006

In April 2000, the government established the Saudi Arabian General Investment
Authority to encourage foreign direct investment in Saudi Arabia. Saudi Arabia
maintains a negative list of sectors in which foreign investment is
prohibited, but the government planned to open some closed sectors such as
telecommunications, insurance, and power transmission/distribution over time.

Saudi Arabia became a full World Trade Organization (WTO) member on 11
December 2005. In 2019, the government established the General Authority for
Foreign Trade to enhance the kingdom's international commercial and investment
activities.

In early July 2020, Saudi Arabia announced the nomination of its former
Minister of Economy and Saudi royal court adviser, Mohammad Al-Tuwaijri, for
the role of WTO's director-general. The nominations were made public about a
month after the WTO reported the kingdom for copyrights infringement following
distribution of pirated sports broadcasting content on the state-owned
broadcast service, BeoutQ. The nomination of al-Tuwaijri received criticism
from human rights groups in mid-August 2020, demanding the rejection of the
Saudi nominee due to the kingdom's violation of human rights in addition to
his silence over it. On 7 October 2020, Al-Tuwaijri, along with other nominees
from the UK and Kenya, lost the bid for the role due to lack of support, as
compared to the nominees from Nigeria and South Korea who qualified for the
final round of selection.

Saudi Arabia is part of the following trade organizations:

* World Trade Organization (WTO)
* International Monetary Fund (IMF)
* International Chamber of Commerce (ICC)
* International Organization for Standardization (ISO)
* World Customs Organization (WCO)
openai_summarised_points: • In April 2000, the Saudi Arabian government established the Saudi Arabian General Investment Authority (SAGIA) to promote and encourage foreign direct investment (FDI) within the kingdom.

• Saudi Arabia maintains a negative list specifying sectors where foreign investment is prohibited, but the government planned gradual liberalization by opening previously closed sectors such as telecommunications, insurance, and power transmission/distribution.
• Saudi Arabia became a full member of the World Trade Organization (WTO) on 11 December 2005, marking a significant step in integrating its economy into the global trading system.
• In 2019, the Saudi government established the General Authority for Foreign Trade with the objective of enhancing the kingdom’s international commercial and investment activities.
• In early July 2020, Saudi Arabia nominated Mohammad Al-Tuwaijri, former Minister of Economy and adviser to the Saudi royal court, for the position of WTO director-general.

• The nomination of Al-Tuwaijri occurred approximately one month after the WTO reported Saudi Arabia for copyright infringement related to the distribution of pirated sports broadcasting content via the state-owned broadcaster BeoutQ.
• Human rights groups criticized Al-Tuwaijri’s nomination in mid-August 2020, calling for rejection due to Saudi Arabia’s human rights violations and Al-Tuwaijri’s silence on these issues.

• On 7 October 2020, Mohammad Al-Tuwaijri lost the bid for WTO director-general due to insufficient support, alongside nominees from the UK and Kenya; the final round of selection included nominees from Nigeria and South Korea.

• Saudi Arabia is a member of several key international trade and economic organizations, including the World Trade Organization (WTO), International Monetary Fund (IMF), International Chamber of Commerce (ICC), International Organization for Standardization (ISO), and World Customs Organization (WCO).

text:
Among the challenges to the Saudi economy include halting or reversing the
decline in per capita income, improving education to prepare youth for the
workforce and providing them with employment, diversifying the economy,
stimulating the private sector and housing construction, and diminishing
corruption and inequality. In answer to the question of why the Saudi economy
is so dependent on foreign labor, the UN Arab Human Development Report blamed
stunted social and economic development inhibited by lack of personal freedom,
poor education, government hiring based on factors other than merit, and the
exclusion of women.
openai_summarised_points: • The Saudi economy faces several significant challenges, including halting or reversing the decline in per capita income, which is critical for improving overall living standards.
• Improving the education system is essential to better prepare Saudi youth for the workforce and to provide them with adequate employment opportunities.
• Economic diversification is a key challenge, requiring the reduction of dependence on oil revenues and the development of other sectors to ensure sustainable growth.
• Stimulating the private sector is necessary to create jobs and foster economic dynamism beyond the public sector’s dominance.
• Increasing housing construction is an important objective to meet the growing demand for residential infrastructure amid population growth.
• Addressing and diminishing corruption and inequality are vital to promote fair economic participation and social stability within the Kingdom.

• The UN Arab Human Development Report attributes the Saudi economy’s heavy reliance on foreign labor to stunted social and economic development caused by several factors: lack of personal freedom, poor education quality, government hiring practices based on non-meritocratic criteria, and the exclusion of women from many economic roles.

text:
Despite possessing the second largest petroleum reserves in the world, per
capita income dropped from approximately $18,000 at the height of the oil boom
(1981) to $7,000 in 2001, according to one estimate. As of 2013, due to the
rapid population growth of Saudi Arabia, per capita income in Saudi was "a
fraction of that of smaller Persian gulf neighbors", even less than petroleum-
poor Bahrain.

Unlike most developed countries, where GDP growth is a function of increases
in productivity and inputs such as employment, in Saudi Arabia the fluctuation
of oil prices is the most important factor in the growth or decline of
domestic production. "Saudi reserves are steadily being depleted, and no
significant new discoveries have been found to replace them," according to
Middle East journalist Karen House.[_as of?_] Saudi population grew sevenfold
from 1960 to 2010, and petrol prices are subsidized and cost users less than
equivalent quantities of bottled water. With production stagnant, growth in
population and domestic energy consumption means a decline in per capita
income unless oil prices rise to match that growth.

After 2015, Saudi Arabia embarked on several initiatives, including Vision
2030, aimed at reducing its dependency on oil by investing in other sectors
such as tourism, entertainment, and technology. [] . Despite a decline in oil
GDP, Saudi Arabia's GDP is expected to grow due to the increase in non-oil
GDP. In the second quarter of 2024, Saudi Arabia's GDP contracted by 0.4%
year-on-year, primarily due to an 8.5% decline in oil-related activities.
However, non-oil activities grew by 4.4%, contributing to a seasonally
adjusted growth of 1.4% compared to the previous quarter.

As of 2024, Saudi Arabia's GDP per capita has surpassed all other GCC
countries except Qatar and the United Arab Emirates. Saudi Arabia's GDP per
capita is estimated to be approximately $33,040 in nominal terms, ranking it
35th globally, and $70,333 in purchasing power parity (PPP) terms, ranking it
as the 15th highest in the world []
openai_summarised_points: • Despite holding the second largest petroleum reserves globally, Saudi Arabia's per capita income declined significantly from approximately $18,000 in 1981, at the peak of the oil boom, to $7,000 in 2001, according to one estimate.

• By 2013, rapid population growth in Saudi Arabia resulted in a per capita income that was "a fraction of that of smaller Persian Gulf neighbors," notably even less than that of petroleum-poor Bahrain.

• Unlike most developed countries where GDP growth is driven by productivity and inputs such as employment, Saudi Arabia’s domestic production growth or decline is primarily influenced by fluctuations in oil prices.

• Middle East journalist Karen House noted that Saudi oil reserves were steadily being depleted with no significant new discoveries to replace them, highlighting concerns about the sustainability of oil-based income.
• Saudi Arabia’s population increased sevenfold from 1960 to 2010, while petrol prices remained heavily subsidized, costing consumers less than equivalent quantities of bottled water.
• With stagnant oil production and rising population and domestic energy consumption, per capita income tends to decline unless oil prices increase proportionally to offset these factors.
• Post-2015, Saudi Arabia launched several initiatives, including Vision 2030, aimed at reducing oil dependency by investing in sectors such as tourism, entertainment, and technology.
• Despite a decline in oil GDP, Saudi Arabia’s overall GDP is projected to grow due to expansion in the non-oil sectors of the economy.
• In the second quarter of 2024, Saudi Arabia’s GDP contracted by 0.4% year-on-year, primarily driven by an 8.5% decline in oil-related activities.
• Concurrently, non-oil activities grew by 4.4% in the same quarter, resulting in a seasonally adjusted GDP growth of 1.4% compared to the previous quarter.
• As of 2024, Saudi Arabia’s GDP per capita surpassed all Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) countries except Qatar and the United Arab Emirates.
• Saudi Arabia’s GDP per capita is estimated at approximately $33,040 in nominal terms, ranking it 35th globally.
• In purchasing power parity (PPP) terms, Saudi Arabia’s GDP per capita is estimated at $70,333, ranking it as the 15th highest worldwide.

text:
The Saudi population is young. About 51% of the total population are under the
age of 25 (as of February 2012). According to a 2013 report by the
International Monetary Fund, up to 1.6 million young nationals of the Persian
Gulf countries (of which Saudi Arabia is the largest) will enter the workforce
from 2013 to 2018, but the economies of those countries will have jobs in the
private sector for less than half (approximately 600,000).
openai_summarised_points: • As of February 2012, approximately 51% of Saudi Arabia's total population is under the age of 25, indicating a predominantly young demographic.

• A 2013 report by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) projected that up to 1.6 million young nationals from the Persian Gulf countries, with Saudi Arabia being the largest among them, would enter the workforce between 2013 and 2018.

• The same IMF report highlighted a significant employment challenge, noting that the private sector economies of these Persian Gulf countries would only be able to provide jobs for less than half of these new entrants, approximately 600,000 individuals.

text:
According to _The Economist_ , the Saudi government has attempted in past
years to raise employment by forcing "companies to fill at least 30% of their
positions" with Saudi citizens. However, "employers complained bitterly about
the lack of skills among young locals; years of rote-learning and religious
instruction fail to prepare them for the job market." However, many argue that
young Saudis couldn't compete with foreigners due to the low compensation and
salaries most companies had used to offer for employees from Asian, Indian
subcontinent, and other Arab poor countries, which this cheap labor happily
accepts; in addition to the bad work conditions, culture, and environment
present in most of the Saudi private sector, largely due to the fact that it
was initially modeled to accommodate very-low-income employees from other
nations, not the Saudi medium-income and somewhat highly educated population.
As a consequence, "the quota has now been dropped and replaced with a more
flexible system".

According to scholar David Commins, the kingdom depends "on huge numbers of
expatriate workers to fill technical and administrative positions" in part
because of an educational system that, despite "generous budgets", has
suffered from "poorly trained teachers, low retention rates, lack of rigorous
standards, weak scientific and technical instruction and excessive attention
to religious subjects".

A 2015 survey conducted by Bayt.com showed that over a quarter (28%) of
professionals in North Africa and the Middle East believe that there is a
skills shortage in their country of residence. This belief was even more
prominent among respondents in Saudi Arabia (39%).
openai_summarised_points: • According to _The Economist_, the Saudi government previously attempted to increase employment among Saudi citizens by mandating that companies fill at least 30% of their positions with Saudi nationals.

• Employers in Saudi Arabia expressed strong dissatisfaction with this policy, citing a lack of skills among young Saudi workers; they attributed this deficiency to an education system focused on rote learning and religious instruction, which failed to adequately prepare young Saudis for the job market.

• Critics argue that young Saudi workers struggled to compete with foreign labor due to the low wages and compensation packages offered by many companies to employees from Asian countries, the Indian subcontinent, and poorer Arab nations, who were willing to accept such conditions.

• The Saudi private sector's work environment, culture, and conditions were originally designed to accommodate very low-income foreign workers, making it unsuitable for the medium-income and relatively well-educated Saudi population.
• As a result of these challenges, the original 30% Saudi employment quota was abandoned and replaced with a more flexible system.

• Scholar David Commins notes that Saudi Arabia relies heavily on large numbers of expatriate workers to fill technical and administrative roles, partly because its education system, despite receiving generous funding, suffers from several deficiencies.

• These educational deficiencies include poorly trained teachers, low student retention rates, lack of rigorous academic standards, weak scientific and technical instruction, and an excessive focus on religious subjects.
• A 2015 survey by Bayt.com revealed that 28% of professionals in North Africa and the Middle East perceived a skills shortage in their country of residence.
• This perception of a skills shortage was even more pronounced in Saudi Arabia, where 39% of respondents identified a lack of adequate skills among the workforce.

text:
Saudi has not been a hotbed of technological innovation. The number of Saudi
patents registered in the United States between 1977 and 2010 came to 382—less
than twelve per year—compared to 84,840 patents for South Korea or 20,620 for
Israel during that period. However, in 2017 Saudi Arabia was granted 664
patents by the United States Patent and Trademark Office, ranking 23rd among
92 countries. The number of granted patents was double that of all Arab
countries combined during the same period.
openai_summarised_points: • Saudi Arabia has historically not been a significant center for technological innovation, as evidenced by the relatively low number of patents registered internationally.
• Between 1977 and 2010, Saudi Arabia registered a total of 382 patents in the United States, averaging fewer than twelve patents per year during this 33-year period.
• In comparison, South Korea registered 84,840 patents and Israel registered 20,620 patents in the United States over the same timeframe, highlighting a substantial disparity in innovation output.
• Despite this historical trend, Saudi Arabia experienced a notable increase in patent activity by 2017, when it was granted 664 patents by the United States Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO).
• In 2017, Saudi Arabia ranked 23rd among 92 countries in the number of patents granted by the USPTO, indicating a significant improvement in its innovation capacity.

• The 664 patents granted to Saudi Arabia in 2017 were double the total number of patents granted to all Arab countries combined during that year, underscoring Saudi Arabia’s leading position in innovation within the Arab region.

text:
Business journalist Karen House criticized the Saudi bureaucracy, explaining
that someone seeking to start a business in Saudi Arabia:

> has to complete innumerable applications and documents at multiple layers of
> multiple ministries, which invariably requires seeking favours from various
> patronage networks and accumulating obligations along the way, most probably
> including having to hire less-than-competent dependents of his patrons.
> Then, for any business of any size, government contracts, not private
> competition, are the financial lifeblood. So this means more patrons, more
> favours, and more obligations. Not surprisingly, Saudi businesses that can
> compete outside the protected Saudi market are few.
openai_summarised_points: • Business journalist Karen House criticized the Saudi bureaucracy for its complexity and inefficiency in the process of starting a business in Saudi Arabia.
• According to House, an individual seeking to establish a business must complete numerous applications and documents across multiple layers of various ministries.
• This bureaucratic process typically necessitates seeking favors from multiple patronage networks, resulting in the accumulation of obligations to these networks.
• The process often involves the requirement to hire less-than-competent dependents of patrons, further complicating business operations.
• In Saudi Arabia, government contracts, rather than private competition, serve as the primary financial lifeblood for businesses of any size.
• Reliance on government contracts entails engaging with additional patrons, securing more favors, and incurring further obligations.

• Consequently, Saudi businesses capable of competing outside the protected Saudi market are relatively few, reflecting the restrictive and patronage-based nature of the domestic business environment.

text:
The cost of maintaining the Royal Family is estimated by some to be about
US$10 billion per year.

A 2005 survey by the Riyadh Chamber of Commerce found that 77% of businessmen
polled felt they had to 'bypass' the law to conduct their operations. By 2012,
"businessmen say it has only gotten worse". Saudi Arabia has been severely
criticized for failing to tackle money laundering and international terrorism
financing. A report released by the Financial Action Task Force on 24
September 2018, says, "Saudi Arabia is not effectively investigating and
prosecuting individuals involved in larger scale or professional [money
laundering] activity" and is "not effectively confiscating the proceeds of
crime".
openai_summarised_points: • The estimated annual cost of maintaining the Saudi Royal Family is approximately US$10 billion.
• A 2005 survey conducted by the Riyadh Chamber of Commerce revealed that 77% of businessmen polled believed they had to circumvent legal regulations to conduct their business operations.
• By 2012, the perception among businessmen was that the situation regarding the need to bypass the law had deteriorated further.
• Saudi Arabia has faced significant international criticism for its inadequate efforts in combating money laundering and the financing of international terrorism.

• On 24 September 2018, the Financial Action Task Force (FATF) released a report stating that Saudi Arabia was not effectively investigating or prosecuting individuals involved in large-scale or professional money laundering activities.
• The FATF report also highlighted that Saudi Arabia was not effectively confiscating the proceeds derived from criminal activities related to money laundering.

text:
Estimates of the number of Saudis below the poverty line range from between
12.7% and 25%. Press reports and private estimates as of 2013 "suggest that
between 2 million and 4 million" of the country's native Saudis live on "less
than about $530 a month" – about $17 a day – considered the poverty line in
Saudi Arabia.


According to UNESCWA Oman and Saudi Arabia have the highest poverty rates
among GCC nations, at 10.1% and 13.6% respectively and Saudi Arabia saw a
notable decline in poverty from 18.2% in 2010 to 13.6% in 2021.

The Saudi state discourages calling attention to or complaining about poverty.
In December 2011, days after the Arab Spring uprisings, the Saudi interior
ministry detained reporter Feros Boqna and two colleagues (Hussam al-Drewesh
and Khaled al-Rasheed) and held them for almost two weeks for questioning
after they uploaded a 10-minute video on the topic (_Mal3ob 3alena_ , or 'We
are being cheated') to YouTube. Authors of the video claim that 22% of Saudis
are considered to be poor (2009) and 70% of Saudis do not own their houses.
Statistics on the issue are not available through the UN resources because the
Saudi government does not issue poverty figures. Observers researching the
issue prefer to stay anonymous because of the risk of being arrested, like
Feras Boqna.
openai_summarised_points: • Estimates of the proportion of native Saudis living below the poverty line range between 12.7% and 25%, with press reports and private estimates from 2013 indicating that between 2 million and 4 million Saudis live on less than approximately $530 per month, equivalent to about $17 per day, which is considered the poverty line in Saudi Arabia.

• According to the United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Western Asia (UNESCWA), Oman and Saudi Arabia have the highest poverty rates among Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) nations, with rates of 10.1% and 13.6% respectively as of recent data.
• Saudi Arabia experienced a significant reduction in poverty, with the poverty rate declining from 18.2% in 2010 to 13.6% in 2021, reflecting notable socioeconomic changes over the decade.
• The Saudi government actively discourages public discussion or complaints regarding poverty, maintaining a policy that limits transparency and public discourse on the issue.

• In December 2011, shortly after the Arab Spring uprisings, the Saudi Interior Ministry detained reporter Feros Boqna and two colleagues, Hussam al-Drewesh and Khaled al-Rasheed, holding them for nearly two weeks for questioning after they uploaded a 10-minute YouTube video titled _Mal3ob 3alena_ ('We are being cheated'), which addressed poverty in Saudi Arabia.
• The video _Mal3ob 3alena_ claimed that 22% of Saudis were considered poor as of 2009 and that 70% of Saudis did not own their homes, highlighting issues of economic hardship and housing insecurity.

• Official statistics on poverty in Saudi Arabia are not available through United Nations resources because the Saudi government does not publicly release poverty figures, contributing to a lack of reliable data.

• Researchers and observers investigating poverty in Saudi Arabia often remain anonymous due to fears of government reprisal and arrest, as exemplified by the detention of Feros Boqna, reflecting the sensitive and restricted nature of poverty discourse in the country.

text:
50% of Saudi Arabia's citizens owned their own home in 2017, a rise from 30%
in 2011 but below the international average rate of 70%. In 2011, analysts
estimated 500,000 new homes per year were needed to match the growth in Saudi
population, but as of early 2014 only 300,000 to 400,000 houses per year were
being built.

One problem is that the government Real Estate Development Fund (REDF)—which
provides 81% of all loans for housing—had an 18-year waiting list for loans
due to pent-up demand. Another is that the REDF's maximum loan is 500,000 SR
($133,000), while in 2012 the average price for a small free-standing home in
Riyadh is more than double that—1.23 million SR ($328,000). However, as part
of the economic reforms undertaken by the government to enhance national
living standards, new funding solutions have been established to boost the
mortgages for existing and new borrowers to help finance their housing plans.
This was announced in August 2018 by the Minister of Housing, Mr. Majed Al-
Hogail.

A major reason for the high cost of housing is the high cost of land. In urban
areas, the price of land has been bid up because nearly all of it is owned by
the Saudi elite (members of the royal family or other wealthy Saudis), who
have lobbied the government for land "giveaways". Landlords have seen prices
rocket by 50% from 2011 to 2013. The owners benefit from these price increases
as they hold the land for future development. To deal with the key "land
banking" issue, the Minister of Housing suggested in 2013 that vacant property
within city limits could be subject to a tax. However, no firm plans for any
tax have been unveiled.
openai_summarised_points: • In 2017, 50% of Saudi Arabian citizens owned their own homes, marking an increase from 30% in 2011, yet this rate remained below the international average homeownership rate of 70%.

• In 2011, analysts estimated that Saudi Arabia required 500,000 new homes annually to accommodate population growth; however, by early 2014, only between 300,000 and 400,000 houses were being constructed each year.

• The government’s Real Estate Development Fund (REDF), which provides 81% of all housing loans, faced an 18-year waiting list for loans due to high demand, indicating a significant backlog in housing finance availability.

• The REDF’s maximum loan amount was capped at 500,000 Saudi Riyals (SR), equivalent to approximately $133,000, while in 2012 the average price of a small free-standing home in Riyadh was 1.23 million SR ($328,000), more than double the maximum loan.

• To address housing finance challenges, the Saudi government introduced new funding solutions in August 2018, announced by Minister of Housing Majed Al-Hogail, aimed at increasing mortgage availability for both existing and new borrowers to support their housing plans.

• A primary factor contributing to the high cost of housing in Saudi Arabia is the elevated price of land, especially in urban areas where nearly all land is owned by the Saudi elite, including members of the royal family and other wealthy Saudis.

• The Saudi elite have lobbied the government for land "giveaways," which has contributed to a 50% increase in land prices from 2011 to 2013, benefiting landowners who hold land for future development.

• To address the issue of "land banking," where landowners hold vacant property to profit from price increases, the Minister of Housing proposed in 2013 that vacant properties within city limits could be subjected to a tax; however, no concrete plans or implementation details for such a tax have been announced.

text:
In 2018, the imposition of a 5% value-added tax (VAT) brought private-sector
growth to a halt. Consumer spending was also restrained after a sharp increase
in prices for energy, electricity, and water earlier in 2018. The kingdom
witnessed a mass departure of around 750,000 foreign workers after imposing
new government levies on ex-pat workers. The government is also forcing small-
business owners to hire Saudi nationals at comparatively higher wages than
foreign workers. Gaining money from large, direct foreign investments is also
not working in favor of the government. Rich Saudis are reluctant to invest
within the kingdom due to the fear of triggering government scrutiny.

On 11 May 2020, the government announced that it would triple the kingdom's
VAT on goods and services, raising it from 5% to 15%. It also stated that the
increase in VAT—introduced due to the country's current financial crisis due
to plummeting oil prices and impact of coronavirus—would also be followed by a
cut in monthly allowance for state workers worth approximately $266, and
financial benefits for contractors. Aramco decreased the production of its
Arab Light grade of crude oil by a significant amount[_by how much?_] to be
shipped to Asia. The firm also cut down oil pricing for its US buyers
following wavering demand for fuel due to the global relapse of the
coronavirus pandemic.

According to the General Authority for Statistics, Saudi Arabia's inflation
accelerated to 6.2% in August 2020, as compared to the same month last year.
The report states that the annual inflation rate increased from only 0.5% (in
June) to 6.1% (in July), before the increase of VAT to 15% from 5% was
introduced, effective from 1 July 2020.
openai_summarised_points: • In 2018, the imposition of a 5% value-added tax (VAT) caused private-sector growth in Saudi Arabia to come to a halt, significantly impacting economic expansion within the kingdom.
• Consumer spending was further restrained in 2018 following sharp increases in prices for energy, electricity, and water, which contributed to reduced domestic demand.
• The Saudi government imposed new levies on expatriate workers, resulting in a mass departure of approximately 750,000 foreign workers from the kingdom.
• Small-business owners were mandated by the government to hire Saudi nationals at wages higher than those paid to foreign workers, increasing labor costs for these businesses.
• Efforts to attract large, direct foreign investments have been unsuccessful, as wealthy Saudi nationals remain reluctant to invest domestically due to fears of government scrutiny.

• On 11 May 2020, the Saudi government announced a tripling of the VAT rate from 5% to 15% on goods and services, aiming to address the country’s financial crisis caused by plummeting oil prices and the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic.

• Alongside the VAT increase, the government declared a reduction in the monthly allowance for state workers by approximately $266 and cuts in financial benefits for contractors as part of austerity measures.

• Saudi Aramco significantly reduced production of its Arab Light grade crude oil destined for shipment to Asia, although the exact reduction amount is unspecified, in response to decreased global fuel demand amid the coronavirus pandemic.
• Aramco also lowered oil prices for its US buyers due to weakening demand for fuel caused by the global economic downturn linked to the pandemic.
• According to the General Authority for Statistics, Saudi Arabia’s inflation rate accelerated sharply to 6.2% in August 2020 compared to the same month in the previous year.
• The annual inflation rate rose from 0.5% in June 2020 to 6.1% in July 2020, immediately preceding the VAT increase from 5% to 15%, which took effect on 1 July 2020.

text:
Saudi Arabia has two stock exchanges, the Tadawul and The Saudi Parallel
Market (Nomu), whose financial markets are regulated by the Capital Market
Authority. The stock market capitalization of listed companies in Saudi Arabia
is valued at $2.22 trillion. According to the International Institute for
Management Development, Saudi Arabia experienced the largest improvement in
business competitiveness of all countries in 2019; the kingdom rose 13 places
to 26th in the world.
openai_summarised_points: • Saudi Arabia operates two stock exchanges: the Tadawul and The Saudi Parallel Market, also known as Nomu.
• The financial markets of Saudi Arabia, including both Tadawul and Nomu, are regulated by the Capital Market Authority.
• The total stock market capitalization of companies listed in Saudi Arabia is valued at $2.22 trillion.
• In 2019, the International Institute for Management Development reported that Saudi Arabia experienced the largest improvement in business competitiveness among all countries globally.
• As a result of this improvement, Saudi Arabia's ranking in global business competitiveness rose by 13 places, reaching 26th position worldwide in 2019.

text:
Saudi Arabia is among the countries with the most notable improvement in doing
business, according to the World Bank Group's "Doing Business" 2020 report.
The country jumped 30 places to rank 62nd in ease of doing business, compared
to the previous year. Previously, the kingdom had been declining in the
overall rankings, from 22nd in 2013 to 92nd in 2018.

According to the World Bank in 2019, Saudi Arabia had conducted reforms in
eight areas of business: (1) starting a business, (2) getting construction
permits, (3) getting electricity, (4) getting credit, (5) protecting minority
investors, (6) trading across borders, (7) enforcing contracts, and (8)
resolving insolvency.

Saudi Arabian companies dominate 2009's "MEED 100", with companies listed on
the Tadawul accounting for 29 out of the region's 100 biggest publicly quoted
companies ranked by market capitalization. Just three of the 20 companies that
have dropped out of the top 100 over the past year are listed on the Saudi
stock exchange.

Foreigners are allowed to wholly own limited liability companies in the
majority of industries. Non-Saudi nationals are required to obtain a foreign
capital investment license from the Saudi Arabian General Investment
Authority.

With a total of 291 foreign investor licenses issued in the second quarter of
2019, the kingdom has witnessed an increase in international investment,
reflecting the economic reforms under the Saudi Vision 2030. Obtaining a
foreign investor license became more straightforward as it requires only two
documents, and it is processed in three hours.
openai_summarised_points: • According to the World Bank Group's "Doing Business" 2020 report, Saudi Arabia is among the countries with the most notable improvement in ease of doing business, having jumped 30 places to rank 62nd compared to the previous year.
• Prior to this improvement, Saudi Arabia's overall ranking in ease of doing business had been declining, falling from 22nd place in 2013 to 92nd place in 2018.

• In 2019, the World Bank identified that Saudi Arabia had implemented reforms across eight key areas of business operations: (1) starting a business, (2) obtaining construction permits, (3) getting electricity, (4) accessing credit, (5) protecting minority investors, (6) trading across borders, (7) enforcing contracts, and (8) resolving insolvency.

• Saudi Arabian companies dominated the "MEED 100" list in 2009, with companies listed on the Tadawul stock exchange accounting for 29 out of the 100 largest publicly quoted companies in the Middle East region ranked by market capitalization.
• Of the 20 companies that dropped out of the MEED 100 list over the previous year, only three were listed on the Saudi stock exchange, indicating strong market stability for Saudi-listed firms.
• Foreign investors are permitted to wholly own limited liability companies in the majority of industries within Saudi Arabia, subject to regulatory requirements.
• Non-Saudi nationals must obtain a foreign capital investment license from the Saudi Arabian General Investment Authority (SAGIA) to operate businesses in the kingdom.

• In the second quarter of 2019, Saudi Arabia issued a total of 291 foreign investor licenses, reflecting a significant increase in international investment aligned with the economic reforms under the Saudi Vision 2030 initiative.
• The process for obtaining a foreign investor license was streamlined to require only two documents and is completed within three hours, facilitating easier access for foreign investors.

text:
Saudi Aramco (officially the Saudi Arabian Oil Co.) is Saudi Arabia's national
oil, petroleum, and natural gas company headquartered in Dhahran. Saudi Aramco
was listed for public trading on 10 December 2019 and had a valuation as of
US$2 trillion as of 12 December 2019.

Saudi Aramco has both the second largest proven crude oil reserves, which it
claims to be more than 260 billion barrels (4.1×1010 m3), and the largest
daily oil production. The company operates the world's largest single
hydrocarbon network, the Master Gas System. Its yearly production is 3.479
billion barrels (553,100,000 m3), and it manages over 100 oil and gas fields
in Saudi Arabia, including 284.8 trillion standard cubic feet (scf) of natural
gas reserves. Saudi Aramco owns the Ghawar Field, the world's largest oil
field, and the Shaybah Field, another one of the world's largest oil fields.

On 16 November 2020, Saudi Aramco announced hiring banks to sell dollar-
denominated bonds with the aim of improving finances after the coronavirus
pandemic caused a sharp fall in the global demand for crude oil. Aramco's
multi-tranche offer was set to run between 3 and 50 years, depending on the
market conditions. The banks hired for the transaction included Citi Bank,
Goldman Sachs International, HSBC, JP Morgan, Morgan Stanley and NCB Capital.
Other banks involved in the deal included BNP Paribas, BOC International, BofA
Securities, Credit Agricole, First Abu Dhabi Bank, Mizuho, MUFG, SMBC Nikko
and Societe Generale.

In 2021, Saudi Aramco made a net-income of 95.5 billion riyals ($25.5 billion)
in the second quarter alone, which was the highest level since 2018.
openai_summarised_points: • Saudi Aramco, officially known as the Saudi Arabian Oil Co., is the national oil, petroleum, and natural gas company of Saudi Arabia, headquartered in Dhahran.
• The company was listed for public trading on 10 December 2019 and had a valuation of US$2 trillion as of 12 December 2019.
• Saudi Aramco possesses the second largest proven crude oil reserves globally, which it claims exceed 260 billion barrels (4.1×10¹⁰ m³).
• It holds the largest daily oil production worldwide.
• The company operates the Master Gas System, recognized as the world’s largest single hydrocarbon network.
• Saudi Aramco’s annual oil production amounts to 3.479 billion barrels (553,100,000 m³).
• It manages over 100 oil and gas fields within Saudi Arabia, including natural gas reserves totaling 284.8 trillion standard cubic feet (scf).
• The company owns the Ghawar Field, the world’s largest oil field, and the Shaybah Field, which is also among the world’s largest oil fields.

• On 16 November 2020, Saudi Aramco announced plans to hire banks to issue dollar-denominated bonds aimed at improving its financial position following a sharp decline in global crude oil demand due to the coronavirus pandemic.
• The bond offering was structured as a multi-tranche deal with maturities ranging from 3 to 50 years, contingent on market conditions.
• The primary banks hired for the bond transaction included Citi Bank, Goldman Sachs International, HSBC, JP Morgan, Morgan Stanley, and NCB Capital.
• Additional banks involved in the bond issuance were BNP Paribas, BOC International, BofA Securities, Credit Agricole, First Abu Dhabi Bank, Mizuho, MUFG, SMBC Nikko, and Societe Generale.
• In the second quarter of 2021, Saudi Aramco reported a net income of 95.5 billion riyals (equivalent to $25.5 billion), marking its highest quarterly net income since 2018.

text:
The Saudi Arabian Basic Industries Corporation (SABIC) was established by a
royal decree in 1976 to produce chemicals, polymers, and fertilizers. In 2008,
SABIC was Asia's largest (in terms of market capitalization) and most
profitable publicly listed non-oil company, the world's fourth-largest
petrochemical company, the second-largest producer of ethylene glycol and
methanol in the world, the third-largest producer of polyethylene and overall
the fourth-largest producer of polypropylene and polyolefin. It ranked 186th
as the world's largest corporation on the Fortune Global 500 for 2009.
Standard & Poor's and Fitch Ratings claimed SABIC to be the world's largest
producer of polymers and the Persian Gulf region's largest steel producer for
2005 and assigned SABIC an "A" corporate credit rating. In 2008, Fortune 500
ranking records SABIC revenues at $40.2 billion, profits at $5.8 billion, and
assets standing at $72.4 billion.

Ma'aden was formed as a Saudi joint stock company on 23 March 1997 for the
purpose of facilitating the development of Saudi Arabia's mineral resources.
Ma'aden's activities have focused on its active gold business which has grown
in recent years to include the operation of five gold mines: Mahd Ad Dahab, Al
Hajar, Sukhaybarat, Bulghah, and Al Amar. Ma'aden is now expanding its
activities beyond its gold business with the development of phosphates,
aluminium, and other projects. In addition, since its formation, Ma'aden
(through the Ministry of Petroleum and Mineral Resources) has collaborated
with the government and local legislators to develop a regulatory framework
for the governance of the mining industry.
openai_summarised_points: • Ma'aden was established as a Saudi joint stock company on 23 March 1997 with the primary objective of facilitating the development of Saudi Arabia's mineral resources.

• The company’s core activities have centered on its active gold business, which has expanded in recent years to encompass the operation of five gold mines: Mahd Ad Dahab, Al Hajar, Sukhaybarat, Bulghah, and Al Amar.
• Ma'aden is diversifying its operations beyond gold mining by developing projects in phosphates, aluminium, and other mineral sectors.

• Since its inception, Ma'aden has worked in collaboration with the Ministry of Petroleum and Mineral Resources, the Saudi government, and local legislators to establish a regulatory framework governing the mining industry in Saudi Arabia.
